awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Nucleobase-Modified PNA for Sequence Selective Triple-Helical Recognition of Non-Coding RNA
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professors Eriks Rozners of SUNY Binghamton and James A. MacKay of Elizabethtown College are studying new methods for molecular recognition of biologically significant non-coding ribonucleic acid (RNA). With the onset of biochemical technologies such as CRISPR-Cas9 for DNA-editing, and the challenges associated with emerging pathogens such as the SARS-CoV-2 virus (novel coronavirus), RNA (ribonucleic acid) chemistry and biochemistry is at the forefront of research.  We know that less than 2% of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) encodes for functional proteins, while over 70% of DNA is transcribed into RNA. The non-coding RNAs play important yet not fully understood roles in regulation of biological processes. Selective recognition, imaging, and functional regulation of such RNAs will be highly useful for fundamental science and practical applications in biotechnology. This project aims to establish new ways of targeting double-stranded RNA, which has been a long-standing problem and practical limitation in RNA biochemistry. Importantly, the project will be broader in its impact through expanding interdisciplinary collaborative research across traditional institutional boundaries and fostering the training and development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) workforce through research and mentoring activities.   The collaboration continues a 5 year partnership that has established a bridge for Elizabethtown College (a primarily undergraduate institution) students, especially women, minorities, and first generation college students for transitioning from undergraduate studies to advanced graduate studies at a research university. Work will contine toward improving STEM education of undergraduate and graduate students, and offer unique training for post-graduate students interested in exploring careers at a primarily undergraduate institution. 

The development of sequence-selective RNA binders is important for understanding the biochemistry of non-coding RNAs and may strongly impact fundamental RNA biology and practical applications in biotechnology and synthetic biology. This collaborative study will develop new derivatives of peptide nucleic acid (PNA) that are potentially capable of recognizing the entire Hoogsteen face of Watson-Crick base pairs of double-stranded RNA. This is to be achieved by development of new nucleobases and binding modes that place two anti-parallel PNA strands in the major groove, each hydrogen-bonding to their respective RNA strand. The properties of the new PNAs will be optimized using synthetic organic chemistry to promote recognition of diverse sequences of double-stranded RNA, which has the potential to solve a long-standing problem in molecular recognition of RNA. If successful, this research will enable a variety of applications, such as, imaging and functional control of regulatory RNA, designer riboswitches for synthetic biology, and inhibition of biologically important RNA for fundamental studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The importance of RNA in science today has been underscored by countless developments and gains in the understanding of its complex biological function. New mRNA vaccines, gene editing technologies such as CRISPR-Cas9, and the regulatory power of microRNA point toward the need for tools to functionally manipulate, modify, and regulate RNA within the field of biotechnology. While most renowned as a mediator between DNA and proteins in the central dogma of molecular biology, we now know that RNA has a host of diverse functions. In fact, between 70-90% of human DNA is transcribed into noncoding RNA (ncRNA), resulting in transcripts of both known and unknown function. Furthermore, the defined and complex structure adopted by many ncRNAs affords opportunity for molecular recognition and the ultimate study of their functional importance. This project continued our work toward the development of new synthetic oligonucleotide nucleobases designed for formation of triple helices with a common structural motif in RNA, the double helix.  Through sequence specific binding, we utilize novel nucleobases incorporated into peptide nucleic acids (PNAs) for binding to double helical RNA through triple-helix formation with the ultimate goal of a general probe that can recognize any sequence of RNA.

The work resulting from this grant was enhanced significantly by the broader impacts aimed at training the next generation of scientists. We used a cross institutional collaboration between Elizabethtown College (EC), a primarily undergraduate institution (PUI), and Binghamton University (BU), a research institution to establish a bridge between undergraduate learning and graduate school. Through a unique postdoctoral position, the first of its kind at Elizabethtown College, we implemented a variety of training strategies. In addition to the postdoctoral associate receiving mentoring and training for a career as a faculty member at a primarily undergraduate institution, they were able to themselves mentor undergraduate research students, teach classes, and conduct research in a PUI setting. The PI also introduced PNA related projects into the undergraduate curriculum in the sophomore-level Synthesis Lab class that both exposed younger undergraduates to the research process and seeded new ideas for research.

Further, during the funding period, we hosted two separate three-day RNA workshops where EC students visited BU, learned more about RNA and the research project, and interacted with BU chemistry faculty and students. The workshop was a key professional development opportunity for EC students affording them the chance to experience a graduate school environment by meeting with faculty, interacting with graduate students, and learning new techniques and procedures in hands-on workshops. It was attended by about 10 students per year and was unanimously praised for the unique opportunity it provided. Through all the above-mentioned activities, we exposed over 50 undergraduates to this line of research, many of whom were women, minorities and/or first-generation college students. These broader impacts infused new energy for research into the Elizabethtown College Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry. Tangible professional outcomes included the publication of two original research articles, one review article, dozens of student presentations at local regional and national meetings, and several student awards for research. The postdoctoral student was able to secure a job as a faculty member at a PUI and graduates of our program matriculated to graduate and professional schools of their choosing.

This funding period resulted in several significant scientific discoveries. We reported the synthesis of several nucleobases based on the isoorotamide core that showed improved binding over previous isoorotamide bases. Through an iterative design process, we gained insight into structural features that both improve or discourage PNA binding to double-helical RNA. Furthermore, given our strong reliance on the 2-aminopyridine (or M) nucleobase, we also reported significant improvements for its synthesis that allow for easy scale up with minimal purification steps. All together, we have improved on PNA as an important tool for double helical RNA recognition. This tool has multiple applications in science and suggests that our synthetic PNA can be utilized for important new discoveries of functional and structural importance of RNA.
